thread.title: Teen almost 'sent home to die' after rare gastric disease
thread.title_full: Teen almost 'sent home to die' after rare gastric disease | Daily Mail Online

author: Hannah Moore For Daily Mail Australia
title: Teen almost 'sent home to die' after rare gastric disease
text:
A 19-year-old girl who cannot digest food and will spend the rest of her life being fed via a tube is determined to get her life back on track.
Barbara Sass was already battling a bevy of health problems such as fibromyalgia and scoliosis when she was diagnosed with severe gastroparesis - paralysis of the stomach - in December 2015.
Just over a year later, the Victorian-based teenager was diagnosed with intestinal failure.
Life changing: Barbara Sass was diagnosed with both gastroparesis and intestinal failure in the last two years, and will never be able to eat again
The diagnoses had come after three years of constant vomiting and struggling to keep food down.
And while Barbara told Daily Mail Australia she was 'confused' and 'scared' by the diagnosis, she also admitted there was a small sense of relief to finally have a name for her condition.
'Being accused by doctors of it being psychological or an eating disorder, being told it was all made up, or all in my head, was horrible,' she said.
'You can't stop it even though you're trying every day and you're constantly so close to death.
'I had to grow up fast because you get no answers from anybody, you just have to keep going.'
Mixed messages: She told Daily Mail Australia doctors often wrote off her symptoms as those of an eating disorder, and her condition deteriorated for three years before she was diagnosed
Because her condition is so rare, Barbara has not been able to meet anyone going through the same thing as her face to face, but relies on a small community of people on Instagram to connect to.
'It's very isolating, my family and friends don't understand. You feel very alone, like you need someone to talk to but there's noone there,' she said.
Barbara has spent the last four months in hospital following a near-death experience, but is now raising funds through GoFundMe to leave.
Before: The teenager was already battling a number of health conditions, but lived a fairly normal life before her debilitating illness took hold
At one point, the teenager said she was told she would be 'going home to die'.
But at the same time a glimmer of hope appeared for the teenager. Doctors had begun to see an improvement in her health after she had trialed Total Parental Care.
TPC is a tube connected to the chest, where a slurry containing Barbara's total nutritional requirements is delivered.
She will now spend the rest of her life with the tube.
If she is unable to find suitable accommodation for herself where her medical machines and other requirements can be safely stored and kept sterile, Barbara will have to remain in hospital.
Making a move: Having spent the past four months in hospital following a near death experience, Barbara is raising money to purchase medical equipment she will need to live outside the health facility and restart her life
Barbara told Daily Mail Australia she would like to go on to study medicine at university, and wants to become an advocate for people with the rare gastric conditions.
As a result, she has turned to the fundraising site to raise money to find a home of her own and pay for her expensive medical equipment.
The 19-year-old is fully aware of what she needs to do to live a healthy life outside the sterile walls of the hospital, and has been given a list of things she needs to have before she can leave.
Risks: She is constantly aware that one wrong move could land her in hospital, or worse, kill her, which is why she wants to be very prepared when she leaves
They include machines to monitor her blood sugar and blood pressure, as well as blood sugar strips and needles, a medical trolley and bags to hold her TPC and IV fluids.
Barbara will also need extra funds to assist with a move and her expected constant trips to and from hospital.
'If I do one thing wrong outside hospital, I risk a blood infection and ending up in the ICU, I can die,' Barbara said.
'That scares me every day.'
